To answer this question, we need to calculate how many minutes are in one Earth rotation. 

One Earth rotation takes 24 hours. To convert this to minutes, we multiply by 60:

24 hours * 60 minutes = 1,440 minutes

So, if you were to sit still and stare at the sky for one Earth rotation, you would have wasted 1,440 minutes. 

Option (A) is incorrect because it assumes that half of your existence is equivalent to 1,440 minutes, which is not necessarily true. Option (C) is incorrect because it assumes that your family's week is equivalent to 1,440 minutes, which is also not necessarily true. Option (D) is incorrect because it does not provide an accurate time frame.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the Earth's rotation and time measurement. The Earth completes one rotation on its axis in approximately 24 hours, which is equivalent to 1,440 minutes (option B). If you were to sit still and stare at the sky for one rotation, you would be spending 1,440 minutes doing so. Option (A) is incorrect because half your existence would be a significantly longer period of time than 24 hours. Option (C) is incorrect because it is subjective and not related to the actual time period. Option (D) is incorrect because it is also longer than 24 hours.
